bibl.title: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, October 16, 1941

div1.p: Kellogg has received favorable comments on the Cornwell painting from Cumming and Kahn. Kahn, a friend of Carlos E. Finlay, reported Finlay's approval.

div1.head: Letter from George A. Kellogg to Philip Showalter Hench, October 16, 1941
div1.opener:
GEORGE A. KELLOGG
257 CORNELISON AVENUE
JERSEY CITY, N.J.
October 16, 1941
Dear Dr. Hench,
div1.p:
Enclosed find two copies of letters, one
from Dr. Hugh Cumming, Director of the Pan American
Sanitary Bureau, and Morton C. Kahn, Associate Professor
of Public Health and Preventive Medicine.

You will be interested to know that when
Dr. Kahn received the picture Dr. Carlos Finlay, Jr., was
with him in his office. Finlay is now down at Atlantic
City at the Public Health meeting.

I talked with Kahn on the 'phone just after
Finlay left and Kahn said that Finlay was very much pleased
with the picture. I think Finlay's attitude toward the
picture is largely dependent upon the attitude of the public
and his friends. When he sees them give approbation, he
does as well.

Mr. Cornwell has been ill for much of the
time during the past month and our plans for the McDowell
picture are going very slowly.

I have just heard from the A.M.A. and they
plan to ship the reprints not later than Tuesday, the 21st.
I hope your shipment arrives in good order.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, George A. Kellogg Dr. Philip S. Hench
The Mayo Clinic
Rochester, Minnesota
